question: A 78-year-old man is brought to the physician by his daughter because of increasing forgetfulness over the past 5 weeks. He had been living independently but came to live with his daughter temporarily after he complained that he was unable to perform some of his daily activities. He has left the front door wide open and tap water running on multiple occasions. He does not sleep well and wakes up 6–7 times during the night. He does not leave his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. He says that he used to enjoy playing the piano but has not played for several months. He has hypertension treated with amlodipine. Vital signs are within normal limits. Mental status examination shows orientation to person, place, and time and psychomotor retardation. He has a blunted affect. Short- and long-term memory is impaired. Attention and concentration are impaired. Neurologic examination shows no focal findings. Serum concentration of electrolytes, thyroid-stimulating hormone, and vitamin B12 are within the reference range. He is very concerned about his memory lapses. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

He has impaired short- and long-term memory, attention, and concentration. 4. He has psychomotor retardation and a blunted affect. 5. The patient is not sleeping well and has daytime sleepiness (wakes up 6–7 times during the night). 6. He has not left his room and rarely makes conversation with his daughter. 7. The patient is concerned about his memory lapses. Given these points, the patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of Alzheimer's disease or another form of dementia. The lack of focal neurologic findings and the absence of other reversible causes (e.g., electrolyte imbalances, thyroid dysfunction) make Alzheimer's disease a more likely diagnosis. Now, let's evaluate the treatment options: A. Fluoxetine: This is an SSRI, which is not typically used to treat dementia. While it may be used to manage depression or anxiety in some patients with dementia, it is not the most appropriate first-line treatment for this patient's primary symptoms. B. Aspirin: This is an NSAID, which is not relevant to the patient's symptoms or diagnosis. C. Ventriculoperitoneal shunt: This is a surgical procedure typically used to treat hydrocephalus, which is not indicated in this case. D. Memantine: This is an NMDA receptor antagonist, which is used to treat moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease. Given the patient's symptoms and diagnosis, this is the most appropriate treatment option. The patient's concerns about his memory lapses are likely related to his underlying diagnosis, and memantine can help alleviate some of his symptoms. Answer choice D is the most appropriate treatment for this patient."}
